subject: Re: on vs. ah
msgSnippet: ... able ... I m an American speaker who doesn t differentiate between the sounds A-h, O-x and AWE but I have figured out what dialects use what phonemes
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "kyudosha" <kyudosha@y...>
wrote:
> I'm not talking about ah vs. awe, I'm talking about A-h vs O-x
> (32/34). I just want to know what the difference is and where to
> find it. Considering as the sounds are so close, I wouldn't be
able
> to hear any accent regardless of which one is used (or ARE they
> close?).

I'm an American speaker who doesn't differentiate between the sounds
A-h, O-x and AWE but I have figured out what dialects use what
phonemes where. Basically, the difference between A-h and O-x is
mostly predictable based on TO:

Use A-h whenever this sound is represented in some way by the
letter "a", except after "w" and "qu". The combination "alm" with
silent "l", however, always uses A-h, so the word 'qualm' is an
exception. For some reason, the prefix "quasi-" uses A-h as
well. 'Father', 'barn', 'Guatemala', 'calm' and 'almond' all use A-
h, but not 'wad', 'wasp', 'quality', 'wallet', 'wallaby',
or 'squander'.

Use O-h when this sound is represented by the letter "o", and in
those instances in which "a" follows "w" or "qu".

So 'wad', 'quality', etc. use O-x, as do 'pot', 'hop', and 'icon'.
